topics.body:
"@Princess♠Molestia":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/538a32496368721f3bb30100#post_538a32496368721f3bb30100
If you have no one to converse to, and you are unfit or don't like to drive. This may sound like a promising technology.
*But if it's serviced by Google*, there is no way in hell I'd trust them.

App controlled appliances exist in a prototype stage right now. But, expert warn of hackers potentially causing danger if the devices are tampered with.

If any of you follow the Mega Man Battle Network series, you'd know what I mean.

[bq="Ore-O"]From back then...:


So, I heard word is on the street that Google's making automated cars.
"Discuss.":http://www.cnn.com/2014/05/28/tech/innovation/google-self-driving-car/index.html?hpt=hp_bn5[/bq]
[/bq]
topics.author: 4fde5cee945b700a970060fc

topics.body:
"@SeraphimDawn":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/538a31e96368721e17ca0100#post_538a31e96368721e17ca0100
"@Princess♠Molestia":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/538a32496368721f3bb30100#post_538a32496368721f3bb30100

If you have flown on an airplane before, you have already trusted your life to an automated pilot. "In fact, the human pilots fall asleep all the times,":http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1374253/This-captain-sleeping-After-week-airline-woe-new-study-shows-shocking-pilots-fall-asleep-flights.html and the plane can fly itself just fine.

[bq]I’m sorry, but I prefer a human being I can talk to, not a bunch of circuitry with no emotion.[/bq]
When you drive alone or let the machine drive for you, you have no one to talk to. When you drive with two or let the machine drive two people, you have someone to talk to. What's the difference? The machine makes talking to others while on the car a safer thing to do.
topics.author: 4fded3ad945b700aaa01381d

topics.body:
"@Grieffon":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/538a37b66368722023120400#post_538a37b66368722023120400
I just don't trust Google.
Plus, hackers with malicious intent can and will tamper with these things. Imagine remote cyber-terrorism, literally.

The fact is, we've survived as a species without this needless technology. I don't think it's safe, nor necessary. Shit will happen no matter what.

"@SeraphimDawn":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/538a38c26368721e64190400#post_538a38c26368721e64190400
I'm not sure if such hacking is even viable outside of movies, but let's assume it is. Very few people have that capability, but anyone can drink and drive and pass the speed limit. I will still trust the self-driving car more.

"Shit will happen no matter what", you say. Then why not just let the machine handle it, so that you can have the 4% of your lifetime spent driving and do something else with it?

topics.body:
"@uc9":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/538a497963687229a4360400#post_538a497963687229a4360400
_*IT'S THE FUCKING SKYNET MAN!*_

"@SeraphimDawn":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/538a38c26368721e64190400#post_538a38c26368721e64190400
[bq="SeraphimDawn"]"@Grieffon":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/538a37b66368722023120400#post_538a37b66368722023120400
I just don't trust Google.
Plus, hackers with malicious intent can and will tamper with these things. Imagine remote cyber-terrorism, literally.

The fact is, we've survived as a species without this needless technology. I don't think it's safe, nor necessary. Shit will happen no matter what.[/bq]
Hacking isn't as easy as you think it is.  99% of the time when most people imagine "hackers" what they're actually thinking of is script kiddies.  Hacking each and every individual car in a city would be near impossible because of a bunch of reason; mainly the first problem of how would you hack a moving target constantly moving out of range of signal, if you wanted to hack a individual car through say if it a gps that is far harder to do than you think cause most gps systems and such already have security against intrusions and so forth.  Also hacking individual street lights isn't as easy as watchdogs makes it out to be.

More realistically speaking if you actually wanted to carry out cyber terrorism by causing accidents you would have to mass falsify a software patch update and let me tell you something; falsifying that you're with the company that makes the software en masse on a large scale is not as easy as you think it is cause most software companies when they issue patches the certificates are not that easy to falsify.  If there was such a attack more realistically speaking it would be a extremely low level attack meant to deny service than to actually hack; basically more realistically speaking if there was such a attack it would be to prevent the cars from accessing traffic reports and such.

Tl:dr; Less end of the world scenario and more of someone being a dick and making you hit traffic.
